;纯 P3HT 薄膜的振动热激子态激发后的极化子对动力学和仅 P3HT 二极管已被研究。我们证明了 p 偏振激发光的入射角以及二极管器件的内部和外部电场都会影响动力学。系统地研究了场致解离以及光和电场致极化效应。

;
;

;摘要

;

;我们研究了有机半导体光电器件中振动热激子态激发后的极化子对动力学，以更好地了解其光物理性质，可以帮助提高设备性能。在我们早期的工作中，发表在 ';Phys.化学。化学。 Phys;., 2019,21, 21236-21248'，我们研究了纯聚（3-己基噻吩-2,5-二基）中静电内部和外部场对极化子对动力学的作用基于设备。由此，我们得出结论，由于器件内部存在内部场，极化子对解离成电荷载流子，并且当在反向偏压下也施加外部电场时，解离过程会加速。除了电场诱导的解离过程之外，我们现在还对光和电场诱导的极化效应对极化子对动力学的影响感兴趣。为此，在本研究中，我们使用飞秒瞬态吸收光谱来研究基于 P3HT 的纯器件中不同光入射角以及静电场附加变化的极化子对动力学。众所周知，薄膜光伏器件可以设计用于改善特定角度下的角度相关响应度，并且光子收集效率取决于光的入射角。内部电场和入射光电场都会影响器件的电荷生成效率，这是由电子激发和电荷形成之间发生的光物理过程决定的。我们的研究表明，入射角变化引起的反射率变化以及电场诱发极化的影响对极化子对动力学产生整体影响。

;德布库玛·拉纳、阿努尔夫·马特尼研究文章洞察纯 P3HT 器件中极化子对动力学的光和静电场诱导偏振：一项基于瞬态吸收光谱的研究10.1002/jrs.6604拉曼光谱杂志10.1002/jrs.6604 https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6604?af=R 研究文章 https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6579?af=R Fri, 29 Sep 2023 01:18:37 -0700 2023-09-29T01:18:37-07:00 Wiley：拉曼光谱杂志：目录2023 年 9 月 1 日星期五 00:00:00 -0700 2023 年 9 月 1 日星期五 00:00:00 -0700 10.1002/jrs.6579使用宽带光纤激光源对相干拉曼散射光谱中的光谱覆盖范围和光谱分辨率进行数值评估《拉曼光谱杂志》，第 54 卷，第 9 期，第 1001-1010 页，2023 年 9 月。使用数值模拟工具使我们能够评估 CRS 光谱的光谱分辨率和光谱覆盖范围。本文介绍了使用全光纤激光源在 C-H 窗口和指纹区域进行高分辨率 CRS 光谱的初步结果。该仿真工具可以容纳任意形状的光脉冲，是一种用户友好且多功能的开源软件。摘要：我们从理论上研究了使用光纤激光源进行高分辨率和宽带相干拉曼散射（CRS）光谱/成像（采用光谱聚焦技术）的可行性。为了完成这项任务，我们开发了一种模拟工具，可以使用分步傅里叶方法直接从任何脉冲传播软件导入激光脉冲参数，以评估 CRS 光谱的光谱分辨率和光谱覆盖范围。因此，该仿真工具可以容纳任意形状和中心波长的光脉冲，也是一个用户友好且多功能的开源软件。我们通过将其结果与已发表的理论和实验数据进行比较来验证数值模拟工具。然后，我们使用该工具研究使用全光纤激光源在 C-H 窗口和指纹区域进行高分辨率 CRS 光谱的可行性。该工具在 CRS 光谱学有用的多个领域具有广泛的应用，例如生物医学、材料表征和生物成像。 ;

;A protocol is presented for design of homogeneous SERS sensors for small molecule detection based on the duplex aptamer mechanism. Using the well-defined ATP aptamer as a model system, the effects of hybridization, ACE, and stabilizer length were explored.

;
;

;Abstract

;

;Homogeneous surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) sensors could have a significant impact in environmental analysis. The reagentless mechanism of these sensors makes them capable for in situ analysis and continuous monitoring of environmental pollutants, without having to collect environmental samples for laboratory analysis. Homogeneous SERS sensors take advantage of functional DNA strands on the surface of a SERS-active particle. These sensors are commonly used for the detection of genomic targets. A clear path to adapt these homogeneous sensors to detect small molecules is to employ aptamer sequences. In particular, the use of duplex aptamer can make these sensors highly adaptable to different target molecules. Although there have been examples of SERS duplex aptamer sensors to detect small molecules, the design rules for this type of sensors have not been elucidated. Without design rules or a design protocol, we would not be able to fully take advantage of the adaptability of this approach to focus on new targets and applications (eg, environmental analysis). Herein, we aim to define a protocol for the design of aptamer-based homogeneous SERS sensors. First, we demonstrate their nonequilibrium character and the necessary length for the complementary element for the sensors to work. We demonstrate the design protocol on a well-characterized aptamer sequence for ATP binding and then transfer the knowledge gained on an aptamer for estradiol, a common water contaminant. In this work, we establish the design protocol for a short aptamer (ie, ATP) and analyze the issues and remedies associated with extending this protocol to longer aptamer sequences (eg, E2).

We performed SERS imaging of intact cell membranes on rough aluminum substrates by comparing them with Si substrates. The comparison of cancer and normal cell membranes revealed different lipid/protein peak ratios in cytoplasm and nucleus‐proximal areas. Abstract The plasma membrane of cancer cells displays differences in lipid and protein composition which distinguish them from healthy cells. Certain molecules have such prominent vibrational characteristics that they can be considered cancer biomarkers. Although Raman spectroscopy is a label‐free non‐invasive method of chemical analysis, it, however, has been limited by weak signals from the membrane compared to the bulk interior of cells. Surface‐enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) on plasmonic gold and silver substrates has previously been used to overcome this limitation. However, the high cost, poor repeatability, and toxicity of these noble metals hinder their practical applications. These challenges may be solved by using different materials and nanostructures. Here, we performed SERS imaging of ovarian cancer cells on rough aluminum substrates and extracted the Raman signals of intact cell membranes by comparing these with the corresponding measurements on Si substrates. We used atomic force microscopy (AFM) for Raman signal calibration. The comparison of cancer and normal cell membranes revealed the different lipid/protein peak ratios in cytoplasm and nucleus‐proximal areas. These Raman signatures of the ovarian cancer can be used as new biomarkers. This method may be extended to other types of cancer biosensing based on aluminum plasmonics. ;

Surface‐enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) combined with multivariate analysis allows for detection and differentiation of dopamine from its metabolite, DOPAC, at physiologically relevant concentrations and in mixtures in artificial cerebrospinal fluid. Abstract Dopamine (DA) is a vital neurotransmitter for brain functions, including pleasure, memory, motivation, and movement control. Dopaminergic neuron degradation is correlated to neurological disorders such as Parkinson's disease, and changes in DA concentration are related to mental health disorders. Currently, the gold standard for monitoring DA concentrations in the brain is electrochemistry. However, although electrochemistry has high sensitivity, it has low specificity for molecules with similar molecular structures, such as DA and its metabolites. Here, we demonstrate that surface‐enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS), a vibrational spectroscopy that provides molecule‐specific information with excellent sensitivity, requires small sample sizes/volumes, and is non‐destructive, is optimal for the detection and differentiation of DA and its metabolites. We show that SERS combined with multivariate analysis allows for the detection and differentiation of DA and its metabolites, including 3‐O‐methyldopamine (3‐OMD), homovanillic acid (HVA), 3,4‐dihydroxyphenylacetic acid (DOPAC), and 3‐methoxytyramine (3‐MT) at physiologically relevant concentrations in artificial cerebrospinal fluid (aCSF). ;

Coherent anti‐Stokes Raman scattering‐Raman optical activity (CARS‐ROA) spectroscopy reduces acquisition times of spontaneous ROA from several hours to approximately 1 min. We present the first demonstration of heterodyne‐detected CARS‐ROA spectroscopy of chiral molecules (MOM‐BINOL) dissolved in an achiral solvent by using a conventional broadband CARS spectroscopy setup. Abstract Coherent anti‐Stokes Raman scattering‐Raman optical activity (CARS‐ROA) is a coherent version of spontaneous ROA spectroscopy, the latter being a well‐established chirally sensitive vibrational spectroscopic technique. A central major advantage of heterodyne‐detected CARS‐ROA over ROA is the drastic reduction of acquisition times from several hours to approximately 1 min due to the high ratio of the chiral Raman signal relative to the achiral CARS background. Here, we present the first demonstration of heterodyne‐detected CARS‐ROA of chiral molecules dissolved in an achiral solvent by using an experimental setup built from a conventional broadband CARS spectrometer. Specifically, the two atropisomers (R/S) of 2,2′‐Bis(methoxymethoxy)‐1,1′‐binaphthyl, a methoxymethyl (MOM) bis‐protected derivative of 1,1′‐Bi‐2‐naphthol (BINOL), dissolved in the achiral organic solvent dichloromethane (DCM) were characterized by employing ~1 ps, 1 mW of pump pulses and ~60 fs, 10 mW of Stokes pulses within approximately 4‐min acquisition time. MOM‐BINOL is an important precursor for the synthesis of a great variety of many chiral auxiliaries including binaphthyl phosphoric acids, which are an important class of chiral organocatalysts used in asymmetric reactions. Overall, this work is a first step toward kinetic reaction monitoring in organocatalysis by coherent ROA providing the necessary short acquisition times. ;

Twisted stacked transition metal dichalcogenides exhibit intriguing properties. In this study, a well‐trained FNN is used to establish a relationship between the interlayer coupling and the twist angle, based on the low‐frequency Raman spectra of twisted bilayer MoS2. DFT and FDM are implemented to determine the interlayer spring constant. By integrating these findings, we successfully construct a twist angle‐dependent linear chain model capable of predicting the breathing mode positions of twisted multilayer MoS2. Abstract The investigation of twisted stacked few‐layer MoS2 has revealed novel electronic, optical, and vibrational properties over an extended period. For the successful integration of twisted stacked few‐layer MoS2 into a wide range of applications, it is crucial to employ a noninvasive, versatile technique for characterizing the layered architecture of these complex structures. In this work, we introduce a machine learning‐assisted low‐frequency Raman spectroscopy method to characterize the twist angle of few‐layer stacked MoS2 samples. A feedforward neural network (FNN) is utilized to analyze the low‐frequency breathing mode as a function of the twist angle. Moreover, using finite difference method (FDM) and density functional theory (DFT) calculations, we show that the low‐frequency Raman spectra of MoS2 are mainly influenced by the effect of the nearest and second nearest layers. A new improved linear chain model (TA‐LCM) with taking the twist angle into the consideration is developed to understand the interlayer breathing modes of stacked few‐layer MoS2. This approach can be extended to other 2D materials systems and provides an intelligent way to investigate naturally stacked and twisted interlayer interactions. ;
